												Plus points first...This offers a level of customisation I haven't seen in any other street racing game. For example, you don't just upgrade a stage 1 engine to a stage 2 engine. You buy individual engine components and assemble them. In the right order. Do you know the optimal air/fuel ratio for a specific type of fuel and engine configuration? You'll need to find out if you want to get the best from your car. What spring rate is best for the suspension setup you have and the intended use of the car? What shock absorber settings? It really is that detailed and it has a strong effect on how a car handles.There's a Roguelike philosophy in this game, in that game over is game over. I had to restart half a dozen times. You start with only one car. If it's damaged and you can't afford to repair it to a working state, game over. Start again. That will probably happen to you because damage is heavy. You're not going to get away with minor damage after clipping a post at 60 mph. Angry or incompetent AI opponents might well ram you. You won $1000 in the race...and they rammed you into a lampost, causing $5000 of non-cosmetic damage. You only have $2400? Game over, start again. And now the negative points:Bugs. The developer of this new version is doing a good job, but they were starting from a game that had more bugs than a square mile of the Amazon rainforest. There are still a lot of bugs (this is true for build 920, the latest build at the moment). Some are irritating. Some are gamebreaking. Some are odd (e.g. on my PC fullscreen is currently effectively broken because the framerate is so low, but windowed mode at the same settings can reach hundreds of FPS)Many of the car parts aren't fully described. This matters because of the depth of customisation. For example, which V6 engine block is best? No way of telling without buying each one and building a complete engine from it, because none of the blocks have any description.The way testing is set up has some flaws. Drag racing is a big part of the game. There's a test track with a drag strip. So far so good. What's not so good is that you have to exit the garage, drive around the outer ring circuit a while and turn onto the drag strip to make a pass and you can't make any adjustments to the car on the test track. So tuning your setup to optimise your drag racing quickly becomes very irritating. Change one front suspension setting...exit garage...drive around ring...make a pass...return to garage...change the setting again...exit garage...drive around ring...make a pass...return to garage...etc. By the way, if you try the mile time on the test track with all but the slowest cars you will run out of track before you can brake and you will ram a wall and you will do a lot of damage, probably destroying your engine. That was the cause of one of my forced game restarts.Bugs. So bugged that it's worth mentioning twice. This is not a finished game (and it's clearly stated as being unfinished and unstable).But I've still enjoyed it for dozens of hours (I usually play offline, so my time on record is a small part of my actual playtime) and I still recommend it despite the bugs and the rubbish testing setup and the bugs and the bugs. There really are a lot of bugs.Imagine a beautiful piece of complex jewellery that has been dug out of the remains of a medieval sewer. A curator is carefully cleaning and restoring it and that will take time. You can see the quality of the piece even though it's still pretty badly encrusted with the dried faeces that is being painstakingly removed. That's SLRR at the moment.

												The game is quite old. It was released in 2003 by Invictus Games. Invictus Games finally named it abandonedware and moved on. Imagecode managed to revive the game and put it on steam. Even till this day, They slowly update this game. What makes it unique is that this is a game using an engine from the late 1990s and was released in 2003, but is still being updated as of 2017.The game is quite fun with tons of tuning and racing. You can tune up a car and take it to a street race, drag race, or another racing event. Career mode can be challenging as you have little funds to buy a functioning car and start racing. If you accidentally crash, the effects can be devastating. You will lose parts and your chassis will become mangled up. And worse yet, crash damage is permanent unless repaired with money. Once you get enough cash and a good car, you can fine-tune your car and decorate it with your heart's desire.The game also uses workshop integration as well as having a large modding community online. There are thousands of mods that add cosmetics, performance parts, cars, and even new tracks.Sadly, the game is NOT stable. Crashes are more than common and can lead to deletion of progress. Every button click makes you cross your fingers in hope that the game wont crash. But luckily, the game is still being updated and patches are still rolling out.Pros:+Classic+Still indev+Indepth tuning+Racing+Challenging+Workshop integration and mods.Cons:-Unstable9/10

I love when i hit my car into something, it damage its parts, Then i fix it by replacing or fixing the parts if it still eligible to use.This game also helps me learn car mechanics. Sadly there's still some things missing in this game, camber, toe, sway bars, spring, shock adjustments, steering ratio, aerodynamics adjustments, and brake adjustments. I know this is an almost 14 years old game, but adding those will make it more and more realistic. Handling physics is okay.Game performance tho is quite bad, Crashes (at start, sometimes in the middle of the game), bugs, glitches, slow downs. But i get that. UI also feels buggy and slow, especially on the main menu. I hope this will get improved alongside updates.Racing is.. well, rather boring. I want to race in circuits with many opponents and be able to configure race options. I want to select specified cars but there are no such things. Maybe you should consider that in the future. Otherwise no comment in this section.Mod support is awesome here, followed by the awesome community who made this game keep alive.Street Legal Racing Redline is suitable for those who wants to learn about cars, learning to drive in virtual city (although there are many better options), racing in circuits and modifying cars. I really didn't think this game was still being developed due to its age but the devs are still going at it to this day and I appreciate that and the fact that they are trying to work out the stability issues which is good. Posted: January 15
												This game has the potential to be a lot of fun, but about half a dozen glaring issues makes this hard to recommend.1) There are a lot of situations that'll force you into starting a new career, the most obvious one is running out of money. Even buying the cheapest car will only leave you enough money for a few races, if you don't make headway with that you'll be out of money with no option but to start a new career.2) The game has about a 1/3 chance of crashing whenever you return to your garage from city mode and if it crashes while entering your garage your car will disappear never to be seen again. I've gone through 3 careers and had this put an end to each one before finally putting the game away. When you enter the game again you'll have all of your progress and cash but your garage will be empty and you'll be prompted to buy another car.3) Night racing scales too quickly and doesn't give you enough chances to make money before your opponents start blowing your car out of the water. I've started with the 19k sports car twice now and it'll carry me through about 4-5 races to the point where drivers start betting 4k each and after that I get pounded into the ground with (seemingly) no option to challenge weaker racers. This leaves you stuck in the position of doing track races (if you can with your car, the sports car only qualifies for like.. 2? out of 59 to begin with.)4) From what I can tell you can't jack up your car in the garage, which causes you to be unable to take certain parts off your car if you want to repair them piece by piece, this isn't a HUGE issue because there's an option to repair everything on your car, but if you have some expensive repairs and want to be selective about what you repair this could cause a problem.5) The early track races get repetitive fast and don't reward enough money to make them feel satisfying. If you start with the $17k wagon you'll qualify for a race that costs $100 to enter and rewards $500 for first place. It'll take about 3 minutes to clear, meaning you'll make roughly $1200 in about 10 minutes of racing the same track. I don't expect to be given 3k per race and have an amazing car grinding the first race, but it does make it a bit too grindy to get to a satisfying place. Also, if you plan on night racing at all, having that grind wiped away by issue #2 makes things even worse.6) The parts catalogue does little to help you in picking out parts for your car. I was thankful that it would at least tell you if you could install certain parts in your car when you went to buy them, but didn't do much to tell you what was compatible with what, and if you couldn't buy it it wouldn't tell you anything at all which makes planning for future upgrades difficult. I'd like to see some sort of part comparison later on that'll make it a bit easier to tell what's compatible with your vehicle in its current state.Those are the glaring issues I see with the game in its current state, but I did have a lot of fun before #2 became a roadblock for me. The customization has the potential to be really enjoyable, I like being able to sell off parts of my car that I don't use for a little extra cash (who needs a passenger seat or doors!?) and the painting booth seems like it could be nice as well even though I never really had the spare cash to use it. As a guy that doesn't personally have a whole lot of experience with cars I could see myself having a lot of fun with this game once it gets a bit more polished, it's pretty approachable already.

												Pretty fun game, although the driving physics are weird, it doesn't look that pretty, and the gameplay isn't that polished. It wouldn't be that good of a game if it was just a racing game, but you can change your car however you like. Want to save weight? just take some seats out. Too slow? Build a better engine. Want to go race it in the city? Go right ahead. Crashed it into a police car and destroyed everything but the chassis? Have fun rebuilding it.Do keep in mind that the game is far from polished. If you damage your car and can't repair it your run is pretty much over, you can still sell your car and get some money for a new one, but you'll be too slow to keep up. Learning how to play is difficult too if you don't look up some tutorials.The thing I like so much about this game is the fact that there's so much stuff in it. A few examples:-Drag racing (cash or pink slip)-Racing-Engine/car building-Freeroaming-Store several cars-Damage model-Police chases-1st person cameraHere are some cons listed too. Some of these can be quite game breaking but these are easily fixable-After a drag race your brakes just get slammed by the game, this can cause you to crash into your opponent or the scenery completly destroying your car ( and wasting the money won)-The police can't keep up with the higher end cars-The game launcher and settings do act quite weird (resetting resolution, tabbing out on launch, Hud numbers not where they're supposed to be (speed and gear are in the black part of the speedo and unreadable)-Some wheels not supported (G29 for example) -Dashboard speedo is extremly inaccurateThis is my first "real" review so criticism is appreciated.

												I've been an SLRR fan for quite some time and I purchased this game to help and support the developers. I got into the game thinking, "I know what SLRR is gonna be like..." Well, I was right and wrong.If you enoyed the previous versions of SLRR (2.2.1 or 2.3.0), you'll definitely enjoy this one as well. The game still maintains SLRR's unique, in-depth, highly detailed tuning/customization. To date, it's the only racing game I've ever played that allows you to build a car from scratch. Players can purchase engine blocks, heads, pistons, connecting rods, exhausts, intakes, camshafts, crankshafts, transmissions, turbochargers, superchargers, fuel rails/types, tires, brakes, springs, shocks, anti-roll bars, seats, pedals, steering wheels, etc. and then you're left to build the whole thing yourself. The tuning possibilities are endless. And if you crash, you pay for whatever damage you've made. If you crash and lose an engine (it's bound to happen at some point, lol), you're gonna have to buy more parts to rebuild another engine.In comparison to the previous versions, this game does a lot of things better. There is a bigger variety of cars to purchase, the physics feel more solid (in my opinion), and the addition of new racing events allows players to race their vehicles on numerous amounts of racetracks, not just the streets of Valo City. Players can now also change the amount they want to wager on night races, allowing you to make some really quick cash.My only concern is the game's stability. SLRR has a reputation for being unstable. It crashes A LOT, and you may come across some glitches and bugs every now and then. The recent updates have made a lot of improvements though. If the unstability isn't a huge concern to you, I would definitely recommend this game, and to anyone who is a car enthusiast.

The game has an insane amount of customization, damn good physics for a 10+ year old game, heightened sense of realism wwhen racing due to the constant fear of crashing and having to repair the car you worked hours on just to build from the ground up, and best of all the mod community for this game is insanely large with tons of mods for this particular game (not on steam workshop, however). Prepare to take off that fender, that door, replace the headlight, inspect your engine for damaged parts, replace the cracked windshield, buy new rims, tires etc. Still want to crash? Nope.
